Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Multiple contemporaneous comments called him a “god”; one commenter heralded the task as “the pinnacle of human brain potential.”
When he started uploading practice videos in 2006, observers marveled at his skill.
A sample comment on one of his practice runs, months before he made history: “that performance... no other way to describe it but... FUCKING LEGENDARY.”
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: A sample comment on one of his practice runs, months before he made history

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: He was still active on online forums.
He kept joining local tourneys, both to hone his skills and to find his people — a small but devout base of DDR players that still, today, celebrate these triumphs of coordination and footwork.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: a small but devout base of DDR players that still, today, celebrate these triumphs of coordination and footwork

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: He visited online friends’ homes to practice on their arcade cabinets, and posted up at arcades for hours, dancing away.
“I had no idea he could do shit like that,” someone uttered in the crowd, in awe, in a video of his display.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: someone uttered in the crowd, in awe, in a video of his display

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Most top-tier active DDR players are in their late teens and twenties.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “It wasn't anything serious,” he told Gazetteer SF over FaceTime from his home in Hayward.
“I wasn't extremely good at the game or anything.”
“He's the GOAT,” according to friend Roger Clark, a San Francisco programmer and longtime DDR enthusiast.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: friend Roger Clark, a San Francisco programmer and longtime DDR enthusiast

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Everybody knows it.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: friend Roger Clark, a San Francisco programmer and longtime DDR enthusiast

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: No one would deny it.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: friend Roger Clark, a San Francisco programmer and longtime DDR enthusiast

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: telling the New York Times he wanted to buy a multi-thousand dollar DDR arcade cabinet.
“We’re learning to pay for things when we have the money,” his mom, who reportedly managed those deals, told the outlet.
“I don’t think I would have any other reason to take it so seriously if it wasn’t for the community and the competition,” he said.
“You discover this group of people who’s really like-minded.
It’s a really rare thing, because out in the normal world, there’s not a lot of people who think like me or have similar hobbies or have the grinder mentality for video games like me.”
“Whenever you meet someone who plays DDR, you kind of don't really care that much what they're doing outside of the game, right?” Clark said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: friend Roger Clark, a San Francisco programmer and longtime DDR enthusiast

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: It’s something that few other elite Dance Dance Revolution players really bother with, Clark said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: friend Roger Clark, a San Francisco programmer and longtime DDR enthusiast

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Clark recalled the song required about 800 steps at 220 beats per minute for two minutes, a feat of agility not entirely dissimilar to an Olympic sprint.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: friend Roger Clark, a San Francisco programmer and longtime DDR enthusiast

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “How someone can even have the physical stamina to do that let alone have the mental fortitude to continue when one tiny mistake is the end of the run … it’s hard to even come up with words for this kind of thing,” Clark said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: friend Roger Clark, a San Francisco programmer and longtime DDR enthusiast

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “It's literally Olympics level, astronaut level.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: friend Roger Clark, a San Francisco programmer and longtime DDR enthusiast

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: He describes it as a blessing in disguise.
“I was, like, I get to quit and have severance at the same time — it was almost a win-win, ‘cause I was already a little bit checked out,” he said.
Chike told Gazetteer he’s saved enough to keep him afloat for a few years, helped along by the occasional brand deal.
“I don't think I can physically do this forever,” he said.
“I'm getting up there, I just turned 33 this week.
So I'm just taking advantage of it while I can.”
“This is the best that anyone in the human race could possibly achieve at this thing,” Clark told Gazetteer.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: friend Roger Clark, a San Francisco programmer and longtime DDR enthusiast

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: He began earning endorsement deals, and was profiled in several mainstream news publications, telling the New York Times he wanted to buy a multi-thousand dollar DDR arcade cabinet.
For his prowess at pretending to play the song, the Guinness Book awarded him a record for best Guitar Hero player in the world.
After graduating in 2013, Chike moved to the Bay Area for work, starting out as a software engineer at GE Healthcare.

In 2017, shortly after Chike won the Konami Arcade Championship (the World Cup of DDR), Clark accompanied him to an arcade in San Jose called Round1, where he planned to set a world record: Completing a level 19 DDR song, the highest level currently available, with absolutely perfect timing.
